metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Owners of Steamship El Madina (respondents)

facts.text: Respondents were owners of steamship called El Madina requisitioned by Government during last world war and lost by enemy action on 16 March 1944.
Government paid compensation: Rs. 20,00,000 on 17 July 1944, Rs. 23,00,000 on 22 December 1944, Rs. 33,333 on 10 August 1946.
Original cost of ship Rs. 24,95,016; written down value at commencement of year of account Rs. 15,68,484; difference Rs. 9,26,532 represents depreciation deductions allowed year after year.
Total compensation exceeded original cost, recouping all depreciation deductions.

Respondents contended before income-tax authorities that Board of Revenue directed for Excess Profits Tax Act that compensation deemed received on 16 April 1944, not in year of account July 1 1944 to June 30 1945.
Income-tax authorities and Appellate Tribunal rejected contention; Tribunal held amount received in year of account, liable under s.10(2)(vii) proviso; order dated July 15 1953.
Respondents applied under s.66(1); Tribunal referred question by order dated February 9 1954: Whether sum of Rs. 9,26,532 properly included in assessee company's total income for 1946-47.

Bombay High Court (Chagla CJ, Tendolkar J) overruled preliminary objection, held question wide enough; on merits held proviso introduced by Income-tax Amendment Act 1946 (VII of 1946) effective May 4 1946 not retrospective, liability as on April 1 1946.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

legal_issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 9,26,532 was properly included in the assessee company's total income computed for the assessment year 1946-47 under proviso to s.10(2)(vii) of Indian Income-tax Act 1922.
Whether in a reference under s.66(1), High Court can consider a question of law not raised before or dealt with by Tribunal but arising out of its order.
Whether fourth proviso to s.10(2)(vii) introduced by Income-tax Amendment Act 1946 (effective May 4 1946) applies to assessment year 1946-47 (liability crystallizing April 1 1946).

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court had no jurisdiction to consider applicability of proviso as not raised before Tribunal, not arising out of its order under s.66(1).
Proviso intended to operate from April 1 1946 despite coming into force May 5 1946.

respondent_arguments.text: Compensation deemed received 16 April 1944 per Board direction for Excess Profits Tax, not in year of account.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 4 Schedule II Excess Profits Tax Act 1940

respondent_arguments.text: Proviso to s.10(2)(vii) not applicable as introduced May 4 1946, not retrospective; liability determined as on April 1 1946.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.10(2)(vii) proviso, Income-tax Amendment Act VII 1946

respondent_arguments.text: Any question of law arising on facts found by Tribunal arises out of its order, even if not argued before it.

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction under s.66 is special/advisory; question must be raised before or dealt with by Tribunal to arise out of its order; cannot import new questions not referred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only questions raised before or decided by Tribunal arise out of its order.

court_reasoning.text: Referred question 'whether sum properly included in total income for 1946-47' wide enough to cover new contention on proviso's applicability without reframing issues.
court_reasoning.key_observation: New contention permissible if within framework of referred question.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso not retrospective; came into force May 4 1946; no basis to deem operation from April 1 1946.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amount not taxable as proviso inapplicable.

holdings.text: A question of law arises out of Tribunal's order under s.66(1) only if raised before or dealt with by it; new questions not entertainable unless within specific referred question.
Referred question sufficiently wide to include contention on proviso's non-retrospectivity.
Rs. 9,26,532 not properly included in total income for 1946-47 as proviso to s.10(2)(vii) not in force on April 1 1946.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Arunachalam Chettiar
precedents_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction under s.66 conditional on order under s.33(4) and question arising therefrom.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Question of sufficient amplitude covers new points if no objection to reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: New Jehangir Vakil Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: s.66(4) limited to questions arising out of order; no new investigations.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kusumben D. Mahadevia v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court jurisdiction limited to questions arising out of Tribunal order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abboy Chetty and Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Question arises out of order only if raised before Tribunal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madanlal Dharnidharka v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Bombay view that questions on facts found arise out of order rejected.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso deems excess compensation over depreciation as profits; reference procedure limits questions to those raised/dealt by Tribunal.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Amendment Act 1946 (VII of 1946)
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced proviso effective May 4 1946, not retrospective.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Deemed date of compensation receipt for excess profits tax, not binding for income-tax.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs, holding that while generally new questions cannot be raised in s.66 reference unless raised/dealt by Tribunal, the referred question was wide enough to cover the contention that the proviso was not retrospective, rendering the sum not taxable for 1946-47.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court judgment upheld; sum of Rs. 9,26,532 not includible in total income for 1946-47.

key_quotes.text: "It is only a question that has been raised before or decided by the Tribunal that could be held to arise out of its order."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of s.66(1) references.

key_quotes.text: "When a question is sufficiently specific, it is competent to the court in such a case to allow a new contention to be advanced, provided it is within the framework of the question as referred."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Exception allowing new arguments within referred question.

key_quotes.text: "A question of law can be said to arise out of an order of the Appellate Tribunal only if such order discloses that the question was raised before the Tribunal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Endorsing strict view from Abboy Chetty.
